thread.title_full: Germany calls on EU to scrap human rights safeguards so migrants can be deported to 'unsafe' countries

author: Justin Huggler
title: Germany calls on EU to scrap human rights safeguards so migrants can be deported to 'unsafe' countries
text:
G ermany has called for the European Union to scrap human rights safeguards so migrants can be deported to countries currently considered unsafe.
Under the plan, asylum-seekers who cross the Mediterranean illegally could be sent back to transit countries such as Libya, Tunisia, and Algeria while their cases are considered.
The proposals come as a leaked German government paper warned that as many as 5.9m people could seek to enter the EU from countries around the Mediterranean.
They would open the way for migrants to be held in internment camps in North Africa while their asylum applications are processed.
But they are likely to prove controversial amid warnings that asylum-seekers’ safety cannot be guaranteed in countries suffering from their own internal conflicts such as Libya.
EU member states are currently debating reforms to the bloc’s current asylum system so it can cope with a repeat of the 2015 refugee crisis.
A policy document put forward by Germany calls for a “crisis mechanism” that would “only spring into action in the event of a mass influx”.
France denied reports that French officials also worked on the paper.
Watch | Merkel: I wish could go back in time on migration 01:43 T he mechanism would be modelled on the migrant deal with Turkey, under which asylum-seekers are returned to the country in return for the EU accepting genuine refugees.
While the policy document does not name specific countries it is clearly aimed at the North African countries from which migrants attempt to cross the Mediterranean.
Following the deal with Turkey the Mediterranean became the main route to Europe.
Attempts to broker Turkey-style deals with these countries have so far faltered over concerns over human rights.
Under the proposals, the EU would drop its human rights safeguards so asylum-seekers can be deported to the countries
Under current EU rules, migrants can only be deported to third countries that are considered safe according to a set of strict criteria.
The proposal calls for the EU to permit deportations to countries which agree not to send asylum-seekers back to the countries they fled from in the first place, and provide guarantees of “safe and humane living conditions”.
Watch | Violent protests erupt in Paris against alleged police rape 00:55 T hese conditions need not exist throughout the country, so long as they are available in specific locations, the document notes.
This appears to open the way for North African internment camps, a proposal that has previously been put forward by Germany.
"This is not about building a 'fortress Europe'. It is about combating illegal immigration, which has already cost the lives of thousands, and about replacing it by a regulated system of legal admissions, combined with humane living conditions, assured by the EU in third countries,” the policy document says.
But the proposals are likely to prove controversial, particularly if they are extended to Libya, the main transit country for Mediterreanean crossings, which is still in the grip of civil war and battling Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (Isil).
“Libya is not Turkey,” Kate Kuschminder, a research fellow at the European University Institute wrote for The Conversation website last week.
The proposals come as Germany’s Bild newspaper published a leaked government report warning that as many as 5.9m asylum-seekers may be preparing to travel to the EU from neighbouring countries.
While Turkey has the highest number, with 2.9m, Libya is second with 1.2m.
